security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no executable code. Contains only markdown files providing git commit guidance. No file access, network calls, or command execution capabilities.

content.value_statement: Messy commit histories make code review difficult and complicate debugging. This skill provides step-by-step guidance for creating atomic commits with clear messages using industry-standard strategies like squash, interactive rebase, and Conventional Commits format.
actual_capabilities: Guide users through git commit strategies (squash, new commit, interactive rebase)
Provide step-by-step instructions for checking branch status and commit history
Enforce Conventional Commits format with type prefixes (feat, fix, refactor, etc.)
Help organize messy WIP commits into clean, logical units
Show how to update existing commits with git commit --amend
Guide force push workflows for amending pushed commits
limitations: Does not execute git commands automatically - provides guidance only
Does not integrate with GitHub or other remote hosting services
Does not provide commit message templates or auto-generation
Does not validate commit messages against project-specific rules

use_cases.title: Clean personal commit history
use_cases.description: Maintain a clean, understandable commit history in your personal branches before creating pull requests

use_cases.title: Standardized commit messages
use_cases.description: Create consistent, conventional commit messages that integrate with automated changelog generation

use_cases.title: Organize review feedback
use_cases.description: Squash review feedback changes into logical commits rather than creating multiple fixup commits

prompt_templates.title: First commit
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating first commit in a new branch
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me create my first git commit for this feature branch. I just finished implementing the feature and want to create a proper commit.

prompt_templates.title: Review feedback
prompt_templates.scenario: Squashing review feedback into existing commit
prompt_templates.prompt: I received review feedback on my PR and made changes. Help me squash these changes into my existing commit using git commit --amend.

prompt_templates.title: Organize WIP commits
prompt_templates.scenario: Cleaning up multiple WIP commits before PR
prompt_templates.prompt: I have many small WIP commits in my branch. Help me use interactive rebase to organize them into logical, atomic commits before creating a PR.

prompt_templates.title: Comprehensive workflow
prompt_templates.scenario: Full commit strategy for complex features
prompt_templates.prompt: I'm implementing a complex feature across multiple sessions. Guide me through the complete workflow: when to create new commits vs squash, how to structure commit messages, and how to prepare for code review.

output_examples.input: Help me commit my changes with proper strategy
output: Step 1: Check your current branch status
- Squash: Best for adding to existing commits (git commit --amend)
- New commit: Best for independent changes (git commit)
- Interactive rebase: Best for organizing multiple commits (git rebase -i)
Step 4: Verify your commit with git log

best_practices: Make each commit atomic and self-contained so it can be reverted independently
Write commit messages that explain why the change was needed, not just what changed
Use git commit --amend for review feedback to keep related changes together
anti_patterns: Creating separate commits for trivial changes like typo fixes alongside feature changes
Using vague commit messages like "update files" or "fix things"
Pushing directly to main branch without using feature branches and PRs

faq.question: What git platforms are supported?
faq.answer: This skill works with any git platform including GitHub, GitLab, Bitbucket, and self-hosted git servers.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of commits I can squash?
faq.answer: There is no limit. You can squash any number of commits using git rebase -i or multiple --amend operations.

faq.question: Does this integrate with GitHub PRs?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides git guidance only. For GitHub integration, use Claude Code's built-in GitHub tools.

faq.question: Is my commit data stored or transmitted?
faq.answer: No. This skill only provides guidance. All git operations happen locally on your machine.

faq.question: What if I make a mistake during rebase?
faq.answer: Use git rebase --abort to cancel and return to the original state. You can also use git reflog to recover lost commits.

faq.question: How is this different from git commit conventions?
faq.answer: This skill combines commit conventions with practical strategy guidance on when to use squash, rebase, or new commits.
